title: Cooperatives – UN International Year of Cooperatives 2025
Types of co-ops
excerpt: Co-ops are found everywhere and together they contribute billions to the UK economy every year. Learn more about the different types of co-ops and who owns them.
highlights:
Highlight:In a worker co-op, the co-op is run for the benefit of - you guessed it – people who do the work. Worker co-ops like Leeds Bread Co-op, Delta-T Devices and Creative Coop are democratically owned and collectively controlled by the workers, who all participate in decision making.

Highlight:These types of co-ops tend to have very flat structures and no hierarchy – some even pay all the staff equally no matter what their role.

Highlight:Producers or suppliers may come together to form a co-op to get a better deal for their products. A good example of this are farmer-owned agricultural co-ops, who work together to share resources and use their collective bargaining power

Highlight:Credit unions like The Co-op Credit Union are good examples of customer owned organisations. They exist to serve the needs of their members, which in this case is access to affordable finance.

Highlight:Community owned businesses can be co-ops and raise finance through community shares. People invest often small sums of money and become co-owners of vital local enterprises – from pools to pubs, community housing to heritage buildings. No matter how much you invest it's one member, one vote, so everyone has a stake and a say in how the organisation is run for the benefit of the community.

Highlight:Multi-stakeholder means a combination of members own and control the co-operative business.  So this might mean a housing co-op with residents and workers making decisions together. Or a multi-million pound retail co-operative where members are elected to have a say to represent customers and the communities where they operate.

title: Co-operative Values and Principles
excerpt: The Values and Principles embraced by today’s worldwide co-operative movement have evolved from the ideals of the early co-operators of the 18th and 19th centuries.
highlights: Highlight:Co-operatives are democratic organisations controlled by their members, who actively participate in setting their policies and making decisions.

title: What's Cooperative Principle #2? Democratic Member Control
excerpt: The United Nations has declared 2025 the International Year of Cooperatives, highlighting how cooperatives build a better world through their vital role in sustainable development, inclusive growth, and strengthening community resilience.
highlights:
Highlight:Democracy is a straightforward concept: it refers to the governance or control of an organization by its members through majority decision-making

Highlight:In primary cooperatives, members have equal voting rights, with one member equaling one vote. Cooperatives like credit unions employ a one-member, one-vote process, regardless of how many loans a member has or how much they have on deposit.

title: What's Cooperative Principle #1? Voluntary & Open Membership
note:
Defines clearly the principle of Voluntary and Open Membership. 
Proposes also several definitions.
excerpt: The United Nations has declared 2025 the International Year of Cooperatives, highlighting how cooperatives build a better world through their vital role in sustainable development, inclusive growth, and strengthening community resilience.
highlights:
Highlight:The voluntary aspect of participation is crucial for cooperatives, as it ensures their sustainability and viability in competitive markets. Cooperatives rely on the voluntary support of their members, who utilize their services and contribute capital through membership shares, which come with voting rights and typically offer dividends or returns.

Highlight:“Willing to accept the responsibilities and benefits of membership” emphasizes that, while membership is open, individuals must also be prepared to fulfill the obligations that accompany it.

Highlight:“Membership” is a core component of a cooperative enterprise, which is collectively owned and democratically governed by those who choose to join based on the cooperative’s characteristics.
